title: MongoDB Atlas - Overview
description:
This dashboard provides an overview of the resource utilization, throughput, and performance of your MongoDB Atlas databases so you can identify and troubleshoot performance issues in one place. 

For further reading on monitoring MongoDB Atlas:

- [How to monitor MongoDB Atlas with Datadog](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/monitor-atlas-performance-metrics-with-datadog/)

- [How to monitor MongoDB Atlas for Government with Datadog](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/monitor-mongodb-atlas-for-government-datadog/)

- [Datadog's MongoDB Atlas integration docs](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/mongodb_atlas/#overview). 

Clone this template dashboard to make changes and add your own graph widgets

definition.content:
This dashboard provides a high-level overview of your MongoDB Atlas deployment so you can quickly identify potential slowdowns and resource limitations.

View key metrics at a glance, such as: total throughput, query efficiency, replication lag, memory + CPU usage, disk space, and more.

**Refer to the following resources for more information**

- [How to monitor MongoDB Atlas with Datadog](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/monitor-atlas-performance-metrics-with-datadog/)

- [How to monitor MongoDB Atlas for Government](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/monitor-mongodb-atlas-for-government-datadog/)

- [Datadog's MongoDB Atlas integration documentation](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/mongodb_atlas/#overview)

formulas.formula: query1 + query2 + query3 + query4 + query5 + query6 + query7 + query8

definition.content:
Replication Operations are executed when the primary server node copies data onto secondary server nodes. 

This can help increase data availability and act as a backup, in case the primary server fails.

Query Efficiency Ratios measure the number of objects or item indexes scanned vs the number objects returned. 

***Lower*** values indicate more efficient queries.

Replication lag refers to the amount of time it takes to copy (i.e. replicate) a write operation on the primary to a secondary. 

Some small delay period may be acceptable, but significant problems emerge as replication lag grows, including building cache pressure on the primary and inconsistent distributed read operations.

Atlas limits the number of concurrent connections based on the instance size of your cluster.

If it reaches that limit, further connections will be refused. You can configure a monitor to automatically get notified when the number of current connections is approaching the limit. This limit is determined by cluster tier.

The ***Disk Space*** graph shows the ratio of free vs used disk space and represents the physical limitation what data can be stored.

The ***Storage*** graph is made up of:

**Storage Space:** The total amount of storage in bytes allocated to this collection for document storage.
If collection data is compressed (which is the default for WiredTiger), the storage size reflects the compressed size and may be smaller than the value returned by **Data Size**.

**Data Size:** Total data size across all databases in bytes. Data compression does not affect this value.

Unoptimized queries might lead to CPU alerts. Also, your current cluster tier might not support the current workload.

**To solve immediate problems:**
Consider adding one or more indexes to improve query performance.

**For a long-term solution:**
You may need to upgrade your cluster to a higher tier to reduce the CPU usage percentage utilized by the current workload.

Disk I/O usage allows you see hardware trends overtime.

High spikes in ***Disk I/O Used %*** can be caused by:

- Unoptimized queries.

- A one-time event which causes a spike in disk utilization such as an index build.

Memory refers to the total physical RAM available on each data bearing node of your Atlas cluster. 

The working set is the sum of all the indexes plus the set of documents that are accessed frequently. If your working set fits in RAM, then MongoDB can serve queries from memory, which provides the fastest query response times.
